content.description: First crack reached at Gorgeous Rocks.

A grab bag of crack widths on this one. The start is the crux. Very safe and easy to protect. Located to the right of Blap (first bolted line on the cliff) and sharing the same anchor.  This safe mellow lead is often used to TR Blap.

climbs.name: Too Many Tacos, Not Enough Toilet Paper

content.description: Start at the bottom of the crack below the tree that is growing out of the wall about 15ft up.  Climb up and to the right, following the obvious crack all the way to the top where there are two anchor bolts.  Decent jugs and cracks for the entire route.  Some areas have awkward opposition holds when placing gear.  Top out is great and there are plenty of places to build an anchor if you don't want to use the bolts.
content.protection: Great protection. No bolts. Anchors at the top.
content.location: Next route to the right of Monkey's Fist

content.description: Follow delicate moves over small crimps, passing 2 bolts to an anchor shared with mixed bidness.
content.location: located to the right of variety crack

content.description:
Boulder-start on a juggy overhang, continue left to a slabby section before coming to the pine tree on a ledge just before the two-bolt anchor. 

  2nd variation (Reach Around, 5.6 ???) can be done simply by directing the rope from the anchors to the far right. This would include another boulder-start that is capped by a small ceiling. 

  Both lines are very fun and full of great movements on stellar rock.
content.location: Relatively safe ledges to set up on from the top of cliff

content.description: Cruise up some easy terrain to the first bolt above the break, move gingerly on some loose but solid flakes to the second bolt, then fire off a v9 boulder problem to the anchor.Â
content.location: Roof to the left of Bat Cave

content.description: The thin overhanging face/arete to the right of the Bat Cave.  Better warm up those fingers for this one!
content.protection:
4 bolts 

  2 bolt Rap anchor shared with the Bat Cave on top
content.location: On the far right end of the Gorgeous Wall, to the right of the Bat Cave

content.description:
Called "Not In the Guidebook" simply because it's not in the guidebook. This overlooked section is definitely a worthwhile climb with challenging moves to exit the alcove and muscle through the wide open rock.  

  To the climber's right of Monkey's Fist. Follow the broken face until reaching an alcove just below a wide crack in overhanging rock. Continue through the opening.
content.protection: Can be set up on Monkey's Fist bolts by simply directing the master point well into the crack.

content.description: Hop up blocks in a big open book and chimney in the corner, past the first roof. Work up the next two roofs to the nicely exposed end.
content.protection: Standard rack. Bolts with rap rings on top of the cliff.

content.description: The crack and arete on the right side of the first wall at Gorgeous Rocks.
content.protection: Standard rack, with 1 bolt to help out.

content.description: Start up the slab (5.6-) to the over hanging section to a nice undercling. From here, a big move with the right hand straight up the face to a knob style hold on a round rock that stands out. From here either left hand to a flake above or match hands and move out right to the upper triangle shaped jug on "the bat cave". From this point finish on the bat cave
content.protection: Top rope only on the bat cave rap station. Lead the bat cave first to set it up.
content.location: Directly to the left of the bat cave.

content.description: This route starts on the bulge just to the left of the Gorgeous Crack.   Climb the bulge to a cool small slot (gear). Continue up, clip the bolt and crank through the crux.  After the crux, traverse 5 feet right, crossing over the Gorgeous Crack and continue up the blank face above. Use delicate moves and long reaches to gain the horizontals above.  Finishes on the same anchors as the Gorgeous Crack and Too Many Tacos.
content.protection: Standard rack.  The low crux was originally PG-13, but is now protected by a bolt.
content.location: Located to the Left of the Gorgeous Crack and to the right of Too Many Tacos

content.description: This hand crack goes up up a steep overhang early on, and is harder than it looks. After surmounting the overhang, the original route finished left on Too Many Tacos.  For a harder finish, continue straight up the face above to finish of the Gorgeous Face (5.10b), or move right to the bolt and finish on the Gorgeous Arete (5.10a).
content.protection: Standard rack. Two bolt rap anchor on top.
content.location: Right side of Gorgeous Rocks, in the middle of the Gorgeous wall.

content.description: Start on the slabby face to the right of the arete for a delicate start, or on the steep face to the left for a bouldery start. Half way up you will get to a good ledge/rest.  From here, traverse left to "Too Many Tacos" (5.7) or continue straight up the "Gorgeous Arete" passing a bolt (5.10a).
content.location: Located on the far right edge of the Gorgeous Wall, before you turn the corner to the Bat Cave.

content.description: This route has a fun crux right at the first bolt, making it a very safe fall.  The route name came from the sound you will make trying to stick the crux!
content.protection: 2 bolts, rap anchor at top shared with Variety Crack
content.location: Located to the left of Variety Crack

content.description: This is the steep chimney on the right end of the Gorgeous wall. Going inside the chimney is much more physical and grungy, but less technical (hence 5.5)  If you hang out of the chimney on the jugs and stem between the two walls, the route is much more fun and technical (5.7), plus you can clip the bolts on the right wall (Party at Tim's) and climb it as a sport route.
content.protection:
Standard rack if climbing inside the chimney. 

  Can also be climbed on the outside using the 4 bolts to the right on "Party at Tim's" (recommended) 

  2 bolt anchor with rap rings at the top.

content.description:
A little hidden crag on the wild side of Glen Onoko. A couple dozen trad, sport and mixed routes, which can also be toproped from bolts and trees, on good rock: Pocono Formation sandstone. It faces northeast and has thick tree cover, so it stays shady. 

  Climbed and developed in the 1990's by Randy Ross, the Miscavages, the Holzmans, Ryan Lucas and Joe Forte, and in the 2000's by Erica Meyers, Jeff Carroll, and Dave Kotch.
